noun.description: The faculty or power of seeing.
examples: Joseph lost his sight as a baby

noun.description: A thing that one sees or that can be seen.
examples: John was a familiar sight in the bar for many years
he was getting used to seeing unpleasant sights

noun.description: A device on a gun or optical instrument used for assisting a person's precise aim or observation.

verb.description: Manage to see or observe (someone or something); catch an initial glimpse of.
examples: tell me when you sight London Bridge
the unseasonal sighting of a cuckoo

verb.description: Take aim by looking through the sights of a gun.

phrases: it was love at first sight
But Cora confesses that it was love at first sight, when the couple met by chance as teenagers, nine years ago.
It was love at first sight - a cosy, comfortable intoxication.
Cupid's arrow stuck at a party five months ago and it was love at first sight.
Although our encounter was brief, it was love at first sight, and before long Travis moved to Seattle to be with me.
origin: Old English (ge)sihth something seen, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch zicht and German Gesicht sight, face, appearance. The verb dates from the mid 16th century (in sight (sense 2 of the verb)).
